9F32D075D6EF4D8782F6148ED6B08105.description: View a variety of artworks from the Renaissance Protestant Reformation as an inspiration for talking about and creating art

54385235E9494BBB81FEB381F3F23956.description: Discuss how the artworks of the Renaissance were different from the artworks of the Protestant Reformation

385411F3BAB4475BADB0E5C333BFCA44.description: Investigate community acts of repatriation and cultural revitalization

E1ABC45ED3F54E1AA94A65732C013C16.description: View a variety of Canadian artworks as an inspiration for talking about and creating art

A3DE5A5360784581B5BACAD6B7BEA1AA.description: Visual arts went through significant change during the Renaissance and Protestant Reformation

89B691AF8E86409DAAE9361EB422B4FD.description: Visual arts in Colonial Canada reflected the changes that occurred in Europe at the same time.

A36539C6B6794CE6A2C18644523C4BAC.description: Visual arts has changed over time as communities and cultures have evolved.

92D718C3D07B429D91118AA63E3E45DC.description:
In response to the Protestant Reformation, the Catholic Church prompted the Counter-Reformation (Council of Trent 1545-1563),
which encouraged a return to
religious artworks, as seen in
St Peter's Basilica, c. 1506-1615
Caravaggio, Supper at
Emmaus, c. 1601

B2CC815AB0D545899AF9B2A9CC04E190.description: Because of the printing press, artworks during the Protestant Reformation became more available for people to purchase

E9C47F2470CA4FCD806E7F808FEB6C34.description: The invention of the printing press revolutionized the way books and images were created and shared during the Protestant Reformation

62E2ADDCBF32467B8DBF50B1CA61B8DB.description: Religious artworks became less popular and artists began to create more non-religious (secular) artwork during the Protestant Reformation, as seen in Rachel Ruysch, Basket of Flowers, c. 1711 Rembrandt, The Night Watch, c. 1642

489953311F0C45DDAEE80E40C68FA9CB.description: Many northern European artists during the Protestant Reformation focused on the daily, moral life of people and explored these themes through landscapes, portraits, still lifes, and historical paintings

9E88D30B776A4E13BCE6B0B7E72326A7.description: Protestant Churches were often plain or painted white

DB2FE2DF79E6410FB59864ED9BA50786.description: Artworks in the Protestant Reformation were a rejection of the religious artworks of the Catholic Church

A740A83F18FC4C51A4E55283497D0DF9.description: Artwork often depicted religious themes and subjects during the Renaissance

777D89505B38477B8C4EA987040C2A5C.description: Linear perspective was used by many Renaissance artists and is still used today by artists to show realistic space

40DEF8652838499582E005F501C7F736.description:
Busts, sculptures of a person's head and torso, and portraiture were popular in the Renaissance and later periods, and can include Donatello, Bust of Niccolò da Uzzano, c. 1430
Hans Holbein the Younger, The
Ambassadors, c. 1533
Raphael, Portrait of Baldassare
Castiglione, c. 1514-1515

CB0B364E3F254447B821A2BB98BB468E.description: Architectural styles in the Renaissance were borrowed from ancient societies and can include sgraffito: a technique using layers of plaster for wall decor or in ceramics loggia: an architectural feature where the outer wall is open to the outside and sometimes supported by columns or arches arcades-a series of arches supported by columns

5EB22D8BD7EB427590C47BAA91BE74EE.description: The Renaissance art movement featured realism and emotion in artworks by representing light through space and by using shadow and reflection in still-life paintings

1C0E2AC496DB498CBA22DADC7FE48B81.description: The Renaissance was a return to creating art in classical styles, inspired by ancient Greece and Rome? examples of Renaissance art and artists can include Albrecht Dürer, Young Hare, c. 1502 Leonardo da Vinci, The Last Supper, c. 1490s, and Mona Lisa, c. 1503 Michelangelo, Pietà, c. 1498-1499 Raphael (Raffaello Santi), The School of Athens, c. 1508-1511 Sandro Botticelli, Adoration of the Magi, c. 1475-1476

1196507924164A92BD080E98C829FB93.description: At the beginning of the Renaissance, artists were known Visual arts went through significant change during the Renaissance and Protestant Reformation. Discuss how the artworks of the Renaissance were different from the artworks of the Protestant Reformation. View a variety of artworks from the Renaissance and Protestant The Enlightenment period rejected the previous art movement, Rococo, which was elaborate and extravagant as profiled in the Palace of Versailles, in France. The Rococo movement was The way in which the visual arts are understood and appreciated has changed throughout history. View artworks from the Enlightenment and the French Revolution as an inspiration for talking about and creating art. Renaissance, artists were known as craftsmen? later in the Renaissance, they became known as artists

76883CCFDAD742A7B297DD3FB5A4C940.description: The Renaissance movement was about all people bettering themselves through education, literature, science, and the arts

A1546095A7D341EEA6B509EF2799FAF6.description: The Catholic Church established a school where arts and handicrafts were taught in early Colonial Canada.

60AC94F4609D4CC69289410C08C83974.description:
In Colonial Canada, some handicraft artists were also considered tradespeople and included
blacksmiths
candle makers
weavers
coopers
printers

F627189CECA74A6AB11AED8B88DD591B.description: Some artists in Colonial Canada were trained by mentors or teachers in the field of art and handicrafts.

DDF7DDE144E247A187F31F0A1BEE5B46.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artworks were influenced by Europeans in a variety of ways, including introduction of glass beads availability of new materials, such as ores not found in North America production of art for aesthetic and economic purposes

D42BF59A334C443788BD77C1B8A03CA3.description: Repatriation of First Nations and Inuit ceremonial and spiritual artifacts is occurring from museums and personal collections and includes medicine bundles totem poles amulets ceremonial clothing medicine pipes bentwood boxes masks headdresses rattles thunder pipe bundles

017B3D3F9BD84209A908F605E94BC37E.description: Repatriation of ceremonial and spiritual artifacts allows for communities to reconnect with culture

629CE9FC94B94C22AFD838447326103F.description: The process through which cultural artworks and artifacts are restored to their rightful people or locations is known as repatriation

27B560F5499E4E87891DD7973FD6FC2E.description: Students investigate how changes in societies of the past have influenced the creation and sharing of artworks.

709FA3364E71400992D086505995AADC.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in visual arts can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great artworks, the artists who create them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

9819C47DA1F242C7A27A26806DF5AD06.description: Apply creative processes to design challenges.

439D39699B7F44EEBA1EEEF95534F3FE.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of artistic choices in the communication of a narrative

2ABD0B90A9E4423CB96D059F728C45EF.description: Make artistic choices when revising or reimagining how a narrative can be illustrated

B508904A0BC4448DAB5F8109CA8100F9.description: Create artworks inspired by art movements throughout history

5BA619CE04CB4B3FA78A8DF084642C7A.description: Explore how narratives are expressed through First Nations, Métis, or Inuit artworks.

C4562A59EEF44D60B021A4890104EBAC.description: Investigate how visual arts have contributed to the preservation of culture in local communities

76507E6AA3F846A2A080E5CB0CB532F0.description: Illustrate a narrative based on a variety of events, themes, or inspirations

A20C30EF4A774B65A9399105305DE07D.description: Create two- and three-dimensional works of art based on a narrative

463D35F353F847F990CEA4B239DA37F9.description: A narrative in visual arts may be perceived by an audience in a way that differs from what the artist intended

B338B90676C24BF7A29846934F4A7938.description: A narrative in visual arts can take the viewer on a journey by entertaining and persuading.

1C6C82D9F62440B39B1FC70E6882F644.description: Narratives can provide connections to culture and history.

304BF477D8664464B376CB12FBDEE16C.description: A narrative in visual arts can communicate knowledge and understandings about the world.

4B40B41AF8294787A5D726216553F9F7.description: A narrative can be structured to describe the past, the present, or the future

907E7723A47047E68F68F010DEC57AC5.description: Creative processes can help solve design challenges when creating artworks.

41B78E33621A4D30B641C39FF9D74359.description: Titles and descriptions provide additional information about a narrative that can clarify what an artist intends to communicate

B05E312C93FA44B2AC0D570AE2593609.description: Parts of a narrative in visual arts may be excluded, leaving the audience to assume what happened before and after the narrative was presented

D3DF0EBFFBA345CE8DE4EBFD3353ED56.description: Artistic choices related to the elements of art and principles of design can be used by an artist to revise and reimagine how a narrative is expressed

8D76FF978D334B649940F67B5A6419E9.description: Universal themes that can occur in narratives include survival, redemption, and quest.

0A5C9B763A3A443FA37B34FF7E7670FC.description: The creation of a narrative can communicate personal experiences stories, legends, myths, and poetry fictional events and characters perspectives

CBDF3CEA42D142C9A2DC34DAFA3B9148.description: Narrative in First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artworks can originate from the land, including wind water soil animals plants

D5D5903B3AD145148BAFA58AA7EBE88C.description: Narrative can be expressed through the spirit or life of First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artworks

5FC624C68AB841E0A02CE2F0B4271089.description: A narrative in visual arts is represented in diverse ways across cultures

4B510D3CC3C54C9FAAF2A4C230863798.description: Art movements are those periods in history where artworks were created with a common goal or style and can include the Renaissance, Impressionism, and Cubism

E1D9BE8E023C403DAE83D9432C81CD7F.description: Preservation of cultural and historical narratives can be achieved through the creation of artworks and artifacts

04B03ADBCB984B38BA8B64D1924198F6.description: A variety of media, including digital art, graffiti, and animation, can be used to illustrate a narrative.

675EC6AD28224A03934B5239A488480E.description: Narrative can be represented individually or collectively

15B915F3C1014F6AA35E2372528ECBD7.description: The structure of a narrative told through artworks can be similar to the structure of a narrative in text.

DF6D1EBBBF8E4E12ADB094C3CFCBBE4A.description: The structure of a narrative in artworks can depict a beginning, a problem, and a resolution.

F905A926662D4E9591515DFD9A672A2F.description: Students represent narrative in artworks based on a variety of inspirations and through the application of artistic choices

163AA68AB7E04E5193CEDF4619578FF4.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented through artworks that draw upon foundational visual arts knowledge

7B13A8743B0340C196144BA085EA37D5.description: Adjust colour and value when illustrating the illusion of space and depth in the foreground, middle ground, and background of landscape artworks.

7667D44EC6634ED3AAA51F8111DFC44F.description: Adjust colour to suggest an effect of light or shadow

2EA712170A6347E382DA32AE6210295A.description: Explore how colour can be used to create illusions in artworks

079C63710B4B41EF9BF23BE5922ED8A6.description: Examine the use of perspective in various artworks

E2B380617C3843EFAE24648A1181CC87.description: Make artistic choices that demonstrate the use of focal points in artworks

F32DC7CDC2744900BA4200C2AB76B237.description: Experiment with how to create focal points in artworks

AEA084675DC5497593EFAB9A36B010BF.description: Discuss how colour can be used as a focal point or as a means to direct the eye when viewing artworks

67E2FE18CB9444D8B0668C05F3FBFD2C.description: Experiment with opaque and transparent colour

9BDF78683AD644908D3F1B40C9DE04CB.description: Examine how colour can communicate meaning or mood in artworks

49BA767C71CD45068788BCDF38E492B6.description: Create artworks using the colour wheel as a tool in choosing a colour palette.

A8701FF436324B4B9C6E1179ABBC3AFE.description: Differentiate between warm and cool colours on the colour wheel

865BF96BAEFB4D788EAE90E912AF0EEB.description: Apply colours with varying values and intensities to artworks

955F3C74A25F47FEBA727569083CB9DF.description: Mix colours to differentiate between value and intensity.

B86B238B80774C968DF32158DA3A1D29.description: Colour can create illusions in artworks

9F667CD400364275BB9A365300AA383D.description: Colour draws the eye to focus on a point in the artwork.

C62C9E17C7A44FC2B011FF7CDFD05D9A.description: Colour can be represented and interpreted in a variety of ways

E82AB8E35FC04968AAB3DE3C0D7589D8.description: Colour is a meaningful and expressive element of art.

80AE7F184B8348C4A8DE88BAE3FE7425.description: There is a relationship between colours, which can be represented on a colour wheel

9F1FFD90FB814F249D98E1B51FBB9C77.description: Intensity is the brightness or dullness of a colour.

261F8149529D42AF86444D9603EC5E7D.description: Colour has the physical property of intensity.

A9341CF5C6694EE8AAB6408DF1EDA1DD.description: Light and shadow can create the illusion of three-dimensional forms, as seen in Willem Claesz Heda, Banquet Piece with Mince Pie, 1635

ED8758AF6B8741D9A07387396F0EEDF1.description: Atmospheric perspective is the illusion of space in landscape paintings, often featuring the use of light colours in the distance, as seen in Albert Bierstadt, Among the Sierra Nevada, California, 1868

3EEE61CC2ECD4414BBB52606585B1637.description: Colour when combined with other elements of art can create illusion, including a sense of depth, contour, or weight by using light and dark shades depth of field and colour value through washes of colour line and space, atmospheric perspective light and depth, colours in the foreground look brighter and more intense than colours in the background

A86D9BD242AE425DADE9EC82679E1F00.description: Colour can be combined with line to create a focal point, including converging lines atmospheric perspective linear perspective and one-point perspective to create an illusion of space in two-dimensional works of art horizon lines

D065AE36CCE74DED80F4D2F3A8601CDA.description: Warm colours tend to advance a focal point while cool colours tend to recede

1047272219394D0090E600948E1A3200.description: Radial balance creates an even pattern of image that radiates from a central point, as seen in mandalas

B56A13645A9948009CBF274ACC3AC056.description: Balance in artwork includes symmetrical, asymmetrical, and radial.

883522D1168B468180C4C2789067F9C8.description: Colour can be used to create focus, as seen in Ted Harrison, Visitor from Space, 1988

17541D61447144CDADCD20A3058C2372.description: Principles of design can be applied to colour to create focus

170404EB5D1C47D7AB57FADADAB00AA1.description: Oil, acrylic, and gouache are the most opaque paints

3540A57569264EB9BD115FE875B2FACC.description: Colours such as red are naturally more opaque than other colours

74D28419145B435A8645F5B335A0DA29.description: Colours such as yellow are naturally more transparent than other colours

83C2599C16C242749CCF1AD86775D8D7.description: A wash can be created by adding water to paint in order to make it more transparent.

C2224E7923F247A8BD82F7B93A13505E.description: Watercolour is the most transparent paint

301E254FB1A54D3CBA66133178BA0353.description: Transparent colour lets some wavelengths of light come through and suggests lightness.

4B8E6BA6D06C446A9D0F2323C208E8EF.description: Opaque colour blocks light and can be adjusted to suggest heaviness.

514EFDE2EF6A4CD3BC7130D8C9091338.description: Expressive colour is used to communicate mood or artistic choice

8C7EDFEEFB2046AFB61775D02005236C.description: Local colour captures the likeness of an object.

8F5BF7C043C549A4B000A4827E8D0499.description: Colour value can indicate meaning, including the following: Dark colours can suggest a lack of light and convey a mood of seriousness. Bright colours suggest positive energy and more light. Red can represent anger, danger, or love. Orange can represent creativity or energy.

45E9A7BD47FB458ABAA28618A553610B.description: The significance of colour can be reflected in cultural or symbolic associations, as seen in Jane Ash Poitras, Mikisew Spirit, 2019

C0FDB8399B0946D3BE2C9A12F0EC5902.description: Cool colours can be found on the blue/green side of the colour wheel.

2DD6B19C995D44B5B313BE37FC33512B.description: Warm colours can be found on the red/yellow side of the colour wheel.

4787D26EEB43453298990981DF5E006E.description: Tints and shades can be created by adding white or black to a colour, as seen in James McNeill Whistler, Arrangement in Grey and Black No. 1 (also known as Whistler's Mother), c. 1871 Pablo Picasso, The Tragedy, 1903

6AEB8313142A4AD3BD0C43F322780572.description: Contrast can be created by placing a secondary colour next to a primary colour

33F69202CEC843338A681AA4D6EEA83F.description: Analogous colours are groups of three colours that are next to each other on the colour wheel.

FA318DE42E1E451985219362C0630A57.description: Complementary colours are those placed opposite each other on the colour wheel.

7203002A77D14068BD3D6DEE9B95F9D3.description: Primary, secondary, and complementary colours can be found on a colour wheel.

B310CF5C6C9C45F7837264786B768094.description: Colour relationships are described as analogous, monochromatic, primary, secondary, and complementary

D031BC3CB16A49F99F9CB3EBED12D4C0.description: In the painting by Pablo Picasso, Le Gourmet, c. 1901, intense colours are used to create a focal point around the child eating.

FA29FEF7E6A34EBEB829596A0CB8F571.description: Artists can use intensity within a composition to direct a viewer's gaze.

2F242C17C5D64535BA7D87A82838F3DF.description: When a colour is neutralized it produces neutral colours including brown or grey

210E0B99877944139C6C890375933922.description: A colour can appear more intense by placing it beside a complementary colour

CF85AB4A77AA48B3ABD7D10063D633F1.description: A colour can appear more intense by placing it beside a complementary colour

F5D340482E5B4D16BCBEF96E7F064870.description: Colours are usually most intense before they are mixed with others

716D7946C4FE439A80F50714D38BB3EC.description: Intensity indicates the purity or strength of a colour

31AF28A2B640439CBCC39752D7C02E24.description: Students analyze colour for its versatility in communicating meaning in artworks

28315A71F73F49C6A0F2D9C19037D4D5.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Visual arts literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles.
